2:50 "... this idea of things expanding from a single point is wrong." I'm not criticizing because I made the same mistake for a very long time. Part of the problem is that many people who speak about the BBT either don't know what they're talking about or are being very sloppy.

The big bang theory draws no such conclusion about t=0. In other words, the BBT is not about the origin of the universe. It's strictly about the evolution of the universe starting at 10^(-32) after the initial "bang." It says nothing about what banged or why it banged. The notion of the universe starting at the so-called primeval atom is based on applying the equations of general relativity to t=0. What can be said is that the entirety of the observable universe was once within the size of an atom.

Having said that, there is no logical contradiction in the idea of an infinite universe that had a beginning. If at any one infinitesimal interval of time, the expansion rate is infinite then you have an infinite universe.

Imagine your garden shed is five metres away from your house, and your fence is ten metres away. If you move your shed further away, that is "dispersal", and it will eventually be restricted by the fence. However, if you move the fence outwards, that is "acquisition" of other land, and permits further dispersal.
Now, imagine that you wake up one morning, and instead of you moving the shed, it has moved two metres by itself. The fence has also moved outwards by four metres. But the shed is also larger, and the fence is higher. You don't even notice, because your house is larger, you are taller, your eyes are bigger in proportion, and your tape measure is longer with proportionately longer markings. That is "expansion".
If space itself is expanding (that is, "stretching"), it would make sense that everything in it is also expanding, including all the atoms, and the individual particles that make up matter. Light itself would also be expanding, maintaining its aspect ratio, therefore not producing red-shift, and a light year would become longer. The result is that we would not be able to detect the stretching. What we are actually witnessing is dispersal. Take this backwards in time, and even if the entire universe were compressed into a tiny space, light would still take the same time to cross it as it does now. That has serious implications for the idea of "inflation".

You keep talking about the evidence that the universe is expanding, but you don't say what that evidence is. It's essentially this: The doppler effect. When speaking of the universe, the red shift. That is, if the source of the light is moving away, the frequency of the light will appear lower than it would if the source was stationary, because the wave is being stretched out over space. It's just like when the train passes you it sounds like the train's horn lowers in pitch. The thing is, the claim that the universe is expanding is a HUGE assertion that cannot be proven. When dealing with space, we do know that we are dealing with vast distances; distances so vast that we cannot observe in real time the motion of other stars. The nearest star outside our solar system, Proxima Centauri is 4.26 light years away. So, it would take over four years to directly observe that it is moving away from us without extrapolation. Distant stars' motion can't be directly observed within a lifetime, or much longer. So the best we can say, if we're honest, is that the universe either is expanding, or at some point did expand. I think that's an important point. If we were standing by a train track and the train passed us traveling at a constant speed and sounding it's horn constantly, during it's approach we would hear the horn at a higher pitch than it's actually putting out. Right at the moment it passed us, for a split second, we would hear the true pitch of the horn, and after it passed and was moving away, we would hear a lower pitch. If we could still hear the horn when the train was a mile away from us, we would be able to tell if the train sped up or slowed down or stopped by the change in pitch, but we wouldn't be able to detect it for a full 5 seconds after it happened. because it took the sound that long to travel the mile between the train and us. It's the same with the stars, but on a much larger scale. Icarus is the farthest star we've seen, and it's 5 billion light years away. It's impossible for us to know whether it even still exists, much less whether it's moving away from us. It amazes me how scientists claim what is at best inductive reasoning as fact.

I will try to describe my view of what "time" is:

In the physical reality the only time is the present. However, the present of any given point in space relates to any other given point at the speed of light. For example, if the earth and the sun are separated by eight lightminutes earth's present and the sun's present are eight minutes apart in either direction. It makes terms like "the observable universe" pointless as it becomes nothing more than an optical phenomenon.

The concept of a "time-line" with a past and a future in addition to the present is entirely a product of the brain. In fact every process of the brain as conciousness, memories, language, perception etc is a tool in the process of creating the experience of time passing.

But how can things be happening all the time(!) if there is only the present? Planets, particles and energy are allowed to move about because they travel across those points in space I mentioned earlier. It is not the distant galaxies that are going faster than light, rather it is the light from those galaxies that has slowed down, at least in our point of view. Remember that nothing does work for free. A photon is no exception to this rule. And so a photon does not travel such large distances without losing some of its own energy, and it gets "tired", and so looks red to us here. The farther it has to go the redder it looks. Other things getting in the way add to this effect too: eg, dust, atoms, assorted other radiation and forces bashing into the photons as it travels to our eyes here. However, this redding is not measurable except in the most extreme galactic distances since it takes a lot to slow down a photon in "empty" space.

This is what Hubble and his pals saw but did not understand in the early 20th century. They assumed it was the Doppler Shift in the light that was caused by the objects moving away from their eyes instead. (FYI Doppler shifts were a fairly new concept back then and something of a new toy for physics nerds, still is today too)

The "tired" photon we see is what makes far-away galaxies look like they are moving faster than light can. But those galaxies are not really moving any faster than most other large objects in the universe do. Occam's Razor is seldom ever wrong.

While I definitely found this a great discussion, to me, it failed to reveal the true nature of the expansion and why it's not necessary for the Universe to be actually expanding into anything. The expansion of the Universe, as I understand, is a relative phenomenon that is created not so much by an actual expansion but rather by the increasing of a scale factor a(t) in the definition of distances. Essentially, space-time is "expanding" because the measurement of distances between two points in space-time is increasing due to this scale factor. Say we have a ruler, and the edges of the ruler never move; however, the definition of how much distance the ruler represents continuously increases over time. So, when we measure distances with our ruler, the region subtended by the two ends of our ruler measure a continuously increasing distance. Since the laws of physics are parameterized by this distance measurement, we will observe phenomenon that is consistent with objects being forced further and further apart, even though they may not actually be moving.

So, as I understand it, the Universe is not expanding in the real sense that we think of expansion (that is, the cartoons of the expanding balloon or the expanding loaf of bread with raisins are mis-representations). Rather, what is happening is that the definition of the measurement of distances between two points is increasing (while the balloon or the loaf actually remain static in their extent), and the Universe and physical phenomenon within it are simply responding consistently with that fact because the laws of physics only operate on the dynamic, measured relative distances, not the static, underlying coordinates.

'What is the universe expanding into' is not a question whose answer 'we can never know'. It is a question we can recognize as a false question! It has this in common with the induction problem of science itself, solved by Popper, through recognizing that it was a false question.

To understand the mistake of this question we must first understand exactly how space comes about. In particular, how come that space has of necessity 3 spatial linear dimensions, and why there cannot be more than those 3.

To know what space is, we have to know what position is first.

Just consider. If something moves, it always moves with respect to something else. If something is standing still, it is always standing still with respect to some objects! We cannot point at a single object and say: that is the one that is standing still! An object, being absolutely at rest does not exist!

And that is because of the Galilean Principle of Relativity, which says that the laws of nature are the same for all observers that do not accelerate and have a definite speed.

But 'speed' is a relative concept! Only the light speed is absolute! That is, the light speed is the same for all observers. And that is, because the light speed is a direct consequence of Maxwell's equations, which are laws of nature, and therefore are subject to the Galilean Principle of Relativity.

To understand why 'where does the universe expand into', is a false question, one must therefore think very deeply about the Galilean Principle of Relativity.

The crucial question one has to ask is this: 'what, exactly, do we mean by position, if we also take the Galilean Principle of Relativity into account?

Or, better, how exactly comes the Galilean Principle of Relativity come about? How is this principle even possible?

Only then we can understand space and time. And only then we can see, that the whole question: 'what is the universe expanding into' is a wrong question, because the idea of 'position' it implicitly assumes, is not a valid concept.

6:30 Mention of the misleading trope "the whole universe started at a single point" and the related "space expanding into" trope. No, that's not what the Friedman solution (actually, the FRWL solution) says or is! The universe at time 0 is still a 3-dimensional space, not a single point.

In particular, only a subset of the space at time 0 lies within any past light cone (i.e. the visible sky); which precludes any notion of space being a point at time 0. The whole idea of "space expanding into" anything or "space being a point" at time zero is based on this bogus visualization of the Big Bang as a Cosmic Egg.

It is not a point at time 0. It just happens to be a 3D space on which distances between points are zero ... which is completely different thing. And another way to say that "the universe is expanding" is that distances between points are getting larger with time. All that can be made to make perfect sense with a perfectly clear understanding, if you remember that in Relativity, spatial distances are in light-speed units. So, another way of saying the same thing is that you have a King's Thumb Problem with light speed, itself. "Spatial distance is 0 at time 0" = "Light speed is infinite at time 0" (i.e. the time zero 3D space is what's referred to as a "null 3D hyper-surface"); and "spatial distance increases over time" = "light speed is slowing down over time". And the "Big Rip" is where light speed goes to 0.

You can see this most graphically, by plotting all spatial points (i.e. all comoving geodesics) vertically on a space-time graph, and plotting instants at equal "cosmic time" (which is a thing in FRWL models) horizontally, and suppressing a spatial dimension. Then light cones get more and more narrow as time goes on; and light speed geodesics become more and more vertical, while at time zero, they become asymptotically horizontal. Not enough is said about the speed of light.  We know, for example, in this space-time (where we are in it) we calculate light at the speed limit of light (in the here and now).  Suppose (supposition) this speed limit doesn't apply uniformly throughout space.  We use this speed to determine distant objects around us, and, we 'INVENT' things like 'doppler shift' in the compression and expansion of frequencies of light (red-shift & blue-shift).  When we look at all the distant objects moving away from us (in every direction) and the objects further away are moving away faster than those closer, we conclude everything in the light spectrum is getting stretched out (doppler shift) away from each other.  Subsequently,  this expansion is multiplied exponentially to a point where expansion exceeds light-speed!  So, we will never be able to see beyond those distant objects we see now.  Our place in this space and time (the here and now) is limited by what we observe.  If we can't see it (or detect it) we can't know it!

But if the universe contains all the space there is, there can be no relatively stationary environment surrounding it, consequently its expansion cannot be discerned. The early universe contained, or was, all the space there is; however, the same can also be said for the later, supposedly "expanded" universe. But how can "all the space there is" be larger or smaller than "all the space there is"? Nonetheless the redshift must indicate something real and universal, even though "expansion" doesn't really describe it. Could we say instead that the universe, rather than getting bigger, is actually attenuating, thinning out? And that the "edge" of the universe is the point at which the galaxies, or whatever form matter takes at that point, begin traveling away from us at the speed of light, which means we can no longer receive any information from them, making them effectively non-existent for us? If the galaxies are traveling away from us at a uniform rate dependent upon their distance, then the distance at which they are receding at the speed of light would remain constant for any point in the universe, or any velocity of the observer. Therefore, the universe is not expanding. And this would hold true even if the rate of attenuation is increasing. If the galaxies are receding from each other at X speed, then the universe has a lifespan of X, the time before ALL matter is receding from all other matter at the speed of light. And if that speed is constantly increasing, this would simply mean that the lifespan of the universe is decreasing, which is true of ANY physical reality as it ages. If we could stand OUTSIDE the universe and observe its rate of attenuation, we could assign a fixed lifespan to it. But since we are INSIDE the universe --- given that the universe has nothing outside it --- its lifespan appears to be constantly decreasing due to the increasing speed of the attenuation. This, however, is no different than our own experience of aging, since we can't (in material terms) stand outside our own lives either: as we get older we experience the passage of time as speeding up, and our lifespan as shrinking. I don't believe that the big bang is proven theory. I don't believe that galaxies are moving away from us, and that the universe is expanding as fast as scientists think. We don't have any way of testing the measurements is a reliable and consistent way of determining how fast or whether or not distant objects are moving away from us.
How do we know that the farther away objects are, the more light waves are stretched ? We don't know the answer to this question. And we don't have any way to test it. So to rely on these tests as factual evidence is not good science in my opinion.
And if we are putting all of our eggs in this big bang theory, we are not able to consider the many other possibilities. We may only be able to determine how reliable testing red shift is, after hundreds or even thousands of years of accurate recorded measurements. I believe that it is better to admit that we don't know, than to try to claim that we do know. It seems like the more evidence that arises that discredits the Big Bang theory, the more the description of the actual big bang changes to fit our current collection of evidence that is considered to be accurate. My point is that measurements and experiments that are untestable, should not be considered as factual. It should be considered one out of several dozen possible theories. It is possible that we don't know how old the Universe is, we don't know how fast distant objects are moving away from us, how many elements are a part of the periodic table, or even many other assumptions we have made about our tests and observations.

As with any good raisin bread, you don't just add raisins in the middle and let them spread out, but instead sprinkle them throughout, and let them expand.

As a student of physics and cosmology for nearly 50 years, I'd like to mention a few things I've learned over that time.

First, my mantra is "Let infinity in the door, logic and reason fly out the window." It doesn't matter what kind of "infinity" you're letting in - it renders all else involved nonsensical. Simply because with the concept of "infinity", anything and everything becomes possible and nothing has to make sense any more. I submit that the concept of "infinity" is in itself nonsensical. When applied to cosmology, "infinity" becomes as absolutely useless as saying "Gawd dunnit" and is about as meaningful.

I propose a better way of thinking about it. Presuming a pre-existing "infinite space" then declaring space started expanding for no apparent reason is a contradiction. Einstein taught us that there is no space alone or time alone but that only the union, spacetime, has any reality. He also taught that it is meaningless to speak of spacetime devoid of matter, thus, matter emerged along with spacetime at cosmic t-0.

Hawking then came along and actually proved, via a reductio ad absurdum argument, in his doctoral thesis that time must have had a beginning - which counters any notion of any pre-existing "infinity" of something, including "space". He also pointed out that the emergence of the positive energy matter along with the counterbalancing negative energy spacetime meant that the net energy of the cosmos is zero.

Therefore, one is forced to conclude two things: 1) The cosmic spacetime manifold is an emergent feature of physical reality, that requires the concurrent emergence of matter, and 2) The cosmos is closed and finite in terms of both extent of spacetime and amount of matter. So what is it expanding into? I posit that the cosmos is temporally finite (13.8 billion years so far) with a finite closed topology that is expanding in overall volume into the future.

If you want to know how to pronounce Georges Lemaître it's doable by an English speaker who hasn't taken any French. The "caret" is called an "accent circumflex" (accent circonflexe, in French), by the way. In this case, in older French, there used to be an "s" following the vowel sound (Lemaistre), but it has been dropped and the vowel sound lengthened. Similarly, forêt for forest, hôpital for hospital, etc.
So, here we go, the differences between the French and the English:
The Gs are softer, the phonetic symbol looks like a weird 3 crossed with a capital J and sounds like the "s" in measure.
French "R"s are produced back in the throat like you are gargling. English speakers are usually too shy with this.
The final "es" on "Georges" is silent.
"M" and "N" are usually more nasal than in English. Open up inside with the tongue and raise that soft palate like you took a big bite of something that was hotter than you anticipated.
Finally, the vowel you were unsure about is between the "e" in bet and the "ai" in bait sort of like "fairy", but further in the nasal passages.

Don't forget, the e on the end of Lemaître is a schwa just like in English, but if you do the French "R" correctly it just happens.
